properties.title: Hippo CMS Tour for Information Architects

section.name: Hippo CMS Tour for Information Architects
section.span: To get introduced to the role of CMS information architect, take the following tour.
section.p: To get introduced to the role of CMS information architect, you will look over the shoulder of Alice, who is working as an CMS information architect for the imaginary organization Swatia, an organization of people very interested in music, art and knowledge. We did not imagine an answer to the question whether Swatia is a commercial organization, a hobby organization, or both.

tr.td: Open the Hippo CMS site http://localhost:8080/cms/ in your browser.
Login to Hippo CMS in the CMS account given to you by your CMS administrator. Alice logs in with her name. Her password is only known to her, so you do not get to see it.

Create a namespace. Swatia decides to publish an online newspaper about music, art and knowledge. The name will be snp, which is just an abbreviation of `Swatia Newspaper'. Alice creates a namespace to gather all the different kind of content of snp in.

Create document types. Alice decides that the online newspaper should at least contain documents for announcing an upcoming happening and documents for describing the author's hobby. So for the time being, she decides to create two document types, which she calls `upcoming' and `myhobby'. You will see her working on 'upcoming'.
Specify type layout. One thing the document type specifies is the layout of documents as they appear to an author in the document editor.

Add date to document type. Alice starts to define the 'upcoming' document type. According to Alice, for upcoming happenings, the date of the happening should always be known, if an article is the be published about it. So she starts with a date field, which she makes mandatory.

Add string to document type. Of course, the articles about upcoming happings should always have a title. Titles should be short and to the point. So Alice adds string field, which she makes mandatory and having a size of 60 characters.

Add boolean to document type. Alice thinks that every author of an article about an upcoming happening should answer the question if the happening is indoors. This allows people who only want to go to indoor happenings, to define a query so that they are only notified of indoor happenings and are not bothered with happenings they are not interested in. So Alice adds a mandatory boolean field called 'Indoors?'.
Alice also wants authors to answer the question if the happening is a recurring happening, a happening that has occured before. Some people only want to go to happenings that have been a succes before, while others may only want to go to happenings that are the first of their kind. So Alice adds a mandatory boolean field called 'Recurring?'.
Add number to document type. Alice wants readers to always know what the entrance price is for a happening. So Alice adds a mandatory long field called 'Entrance price in Euro'.

Add marked-up text to document type. Well, an article about an upcoming happening should allow for a description of the happening. However, that should be optional, as the title may in some cases be enough. So Alice adds a optional markuped text field, called 'Description'.

Change field in document type. Alice decides that the title of an 'upcoming' article, may be more than 60 characters. She decides that the maximum number of characters should be 68. So she changes the size value for the title field.
Remove field from document type. Alice adds another field, does not like it, and removes it again.
Save document type. Alice saves her new document type called 'upcoming'.
Create custom compound. Alice decides to create a custom compound containing some key information that see wants to include in several document types.
